title: Bottom 14 Championship
text:
The Bottom 14 Championship was a <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> knockout competition held by the <a href="Rugby%20Football%20League">Rugby Football League</a> in the <a href="1964%E2%80%9365%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1964–65 season</a>. The competition was used by RFL secretary <a href="Bill%20Fallowfield">Bill Fallowfield</a> to trial an experimental rule change where the <a href="play-the-ball">play-the-ball</a> was replaced with an alternative method of releasing the ball similar to <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>. The tournament lasted only one season, and was won by <a href="Huddersfield%20Giants">Huddersfield</a>.
Background.
In February 1965, the <a href="Rugby%20Football%20League">Rugby Football League</a> (RFL) announced that a competition would be staged at the end of the <a href="1964%E2%80%9365%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1964–65 season</a> for the bottom 14 clubs, and would be used to trial an alternative method of <a href="play-the-ball">playing the ball</a>. The experiment was one of several attempts by the RFL to find a solution to discourage negative tactics being used by teams to keep possession of the ball.
Although some clubs declined to take part, the competition went ahead as planned. The final was contested by <a href="Doncaster%20R.L.F.C.">Doncaster</a> and <a href="Huddersfield%20Giants">Huddersfield</a> at <a href="Tattersfield">Tattersfield</a>, with Huddersfield winning 13–3 in front of a crowd of 2,450.
The competition was not held again after the 1964–65 season, and the rule change was ultimately rejected at the RFL's annual general meeting.
